revisions.rev:
{{Infobox musical artist |name = Mark Gormley |image = Mark_Gormley.JPG |caption = |background = solo_singer |instrument = [[Vocals]], [[Guitar]] |genre = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[Acoustic music|acoustic rock]], [[folk rock]], [[outsider music]] |occupation = [[Musician]], [[Singer-songwriter]], [[United States Marine Corps|Marine (Retired)]] |years_active = |label = UZ Media |associated_acts = |website = }}
'''Mark Gormley''' is a [[singer-songwriter]] from [[Pensacola, Florida]]<ref name="Blender">{{cite web|url=http://www.blender.com/2009/01/viral-musician-to-watch-mark-gormley/|title=Viral Musician To Watch: Mark Gormley |last=Schaefer|first=Sarah|date=January 14, 2009|publisher=''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]''|accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref> who achieved [[Internet celebrity|internet fame]] for his music videos on [[YouTube]].<ref name="Metro 2">{{cite web|url=http://theridiculant.metro.co.uk/2010/01/mark-gormley-returns-on-the-moon.html|title=Mark Gormley returns, on the Moon|publisher=''[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]''|accessdate=2010-01-27}}</ref> He mostly performs [[acoustic music|acoustic rock]] consisting of acoustic guitar and vocals.
==Early years== Gormley learned to play the guitar as a teenager and later wrote a number of original compositions in the mid-1970s.<ref name="videogum" /><ref name="G4TV" /> His musical influences include [[Led Zeppelin]], [[Bob Dylan]], [[Rush (band)|Rush]], [[Jimi Hendrix]], [[James Taylor]] and [[Boston (band)|Boston]].<ref name="videogum" /> During his time enlisted in the [[United States Marine Corps|Marines]], Gormley was stationed in Scotland where he recorded a demo for his songs, but he was unable to gain a recording contract on his return to the USA.<ref name="G4TV" /> In 1986, Gormley entered the music studio once again to record two new songs.<ref name="videogum" />
==''The Uncharted Zone''== Having decided to give up pursuing a career as a musician, Gormley didn't release his music to the public until his first music video was filmed in 2006.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://videogum.com/archives/music-related-content/this-is-your-dads-music-video_045241.html|title=This Is Your Dad's Music Video|date=January 13, 2009|publisher=''[[Stereogum|Videogum]]''|accessdate=2010-01-07}}</ref> Gormley was given a platform when his music videos appeared on ''The Uncharted Zone'',<ref name="Coilhouse">{{cite web|url=http://coilhouse.net/2009/01/mark-gormley-is-love/#more-5460|title=Mark Gormley is Love|last=Yayanos|first=Meredith|date=January 16, 2009|publisher=''Coilhouse Magazine''|accessdate=2010-01-08}}</ref> a weekly [[public-access television]] music show that plays original and cover videos by local artists.<ref name="Infocus">{{cite web|url=http://www.infocus-magazine.com/article/PensacolaConnection/108/|title=Pensacola Connection|last=Manning|first=Ken|date=June 30, 2010|publisher=''Infocus Magazine''|accessdate=2010-07-16}}</ref> ''The Uncharted Zone'' is shown on the [[Blab Television]] cable station<ref name="Infocus" /> and is based in the Gulf Coast of [[Florida]].<ref name="Vice" /> Gormley has since recorded a number of music videos for the show.
The low-budget music videos are produced by Phil Thomas Katt,<ref name="Infocus" /><ref name="Metro" /> a local musician<ref name="Infocus" /> and former radio DJ.<ref name="Vice" /> The videos are characterised by their frequent use of [[Chroma key|green screen]] effects, local scenery and, quite often, comedic or dramatic story lines.<ref name="Metro">{{cite web|url=http://theridiculant.metro.co.uk/2009/01/the-wonderful-world-of-mark-gormley.html|title=The Wonderful World of Mark Gormley|publisher=''[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]''|accessdate=2010-01-07}}</ref><ref name="PNJ" /> Katt runs ''The Uncharted Zone'' with his co-host and longtime friend Tommy Robinetti.<ref name="Vice">{{cite web|url=http://www.viceland.com/wp/2009/01/the-uncharted-zone-with-phil-thomas-katt/|title=The Uncharted Zone with Phil Thomas Katt|last=Herrman|first=John|date=January 29, 2009|publisher=''[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]]''|accessdate=2010-01-16}}</ref><ref name="PNJ">{{cite web|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/pnj/access/2061749651.html?FMT=ABS&date=Jun+19%2C+2010|title=Pensacola's music man: Phil Thomas Katt|last=Ross|first=Rebecca|date=June 19, 2010|publisher=''[[Pensacola News Journal]]''|accessdate=2010-07-17}}</ref> The two can be found introducing each video with quirky commentary and anecdotes about each featured artist.<ref name="Infocus" />
In addition to the television broadcast, ''The Uncharted Zone'' began posting videos on YouTube in 2007. These videos gained popularity during 2009. In a 2010 interview, Phil Thomas Katt explained: ''âThe videos had been on YouTube for a while, and then, last year, things really took off.â''<ref name="PNJ" /> Thanks to these YouTube videos, Katt became a cult icon to a growing group of fans and fellow musicians, and Gormley was propelled to internet stardom.<ref name="PNJ" />
In October 2010, Gormley received the first ever ''The Uncharted Zone'' 'Youzie Award'.<ref name="Youzie"/> The award signified Gormley becoming the first artist in ''The Uncharted Zone's'' history to have a music video surpass one million views on YouTube.<ref name="Youzie">{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IGktTdRBFbU|title=Mark Gormley Receives "Youzie Award" 2010|date=October 15, 2010|publisher=''The Uncharted Zone''|accessdate=2010-10-16}}</ref>
==Internet fame== Gormley's music videos have reached an audience of millions on YouTube.<ref name="G4TV">{{cite web|url=http://g4tv.com/attackoftheshow/whoswhoonyoutube/66295/mark-gormley-accidental-youtube-star.html|title=Mark Gormley, Accidental YouTube Star|last=Morton|first=Eugene|date=February 24, 2009|publisher=''[[G4TV]]''|accessdate=2010-01-07}}</ref> In an article on Gormley, UK-based newspaper ''[[Metro (Associated Metro Limited)|Metro]]'' proclaimed "The internet has a new musical hero in the form of singer-songwriter Mark Gormley".<ref name="Metro" /> Gormley and his music have been featured on the [[G4TV]] television program ''[[Attack of the Show!]]''.<ref name="G4TV" /> [["Weird Al" Yankovic]] performed an [[Impressionist (entertainment)|impression]] of Gormley during an appearance on the television program ''[[Web Soup]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://g4tv.com/videos/39553/weird-al-yankovic-melts-down-on-web-soup/|title=Weird Al Yankovic Melts Down on Web Soup|date=June 29, 2009|publisher=''[[G4 (TV channel)|G4TV]]''|accessdate=2010-01-28}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://blog.rifftrax.com/2009/06/29/rifftrax-is-the-center-of-the-universe/|title=Rifftrax is the Center of the Universe|last=Corbett|first=Bill|date=June 29, 2009|publisher=''[[RiffTrax]]''|accessdate=2010-01-28}}</ref> Gormley has been the inspiration for several fan-made videos, including remixes of his songs, cover versions, and parodies of his music videos.<ref name="videogum3">{{cite web|url=http://videogum.com/archives/music_related_content/the_first_of_probably_many_mar_056061.html|title=The First of Probably Many Mark Gormley Parodies|date=March 3, 2009|publisher=''[[Stereogum|Videogum]]''|accessdate=2010-02-11}}</ref> The standing posture adopted by Gormley in several of his music videos, known as the "Power Stance", became an [[internet meme]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cracked.com/funny-4875-power-stance/|title=Cracked Topics: Power Stance|publisher=''[[Cracked.com]]''|accessdate=2011-01-08}}</ref>
Gormley has been asked to perform by concert bookers and TV shows including the late-night talk show ''[[Jimmy Kimmel Live!]]'', but he decided to decline the offers.<ref name="videogum">{{cite web|url=http://videogum.com/archives/music-related-content/mark-gormley-talks-about-his-i_048561.html|title=Mark Gormley Talks About His Internet Fame; Remains Adorable And Grounded|date=January 27, 2009|publisher=''[[Stereogum|Videogum]]''|accessdate=2010-01-07}}</ref><ref name="videogum2">{{cite web|url=http://videogum.com/archives/music-related-content/mark-gormleys-first-new-video_055061.html|title=Mark Gormley's First New Video Since His Worldwide Fame Happened! |date=February 25, 2009|publisher=''[[Stereogum|Videogum]]''|accessdate=2010-01-13}}</ref> Gormley has avoided the spotlight and is notoriously [[Recluse|reclusive]].<ref name="videogum3" /> In an interview conducted by ''The Uncharted Zone's'' Michele Carnley, Gormley claimed ''âI'm just little old me from Pensacola.â''<ref name="videogum2" /> When asked about his sudden internet fame, Gormley replied ''âIt's a bit overwhelming. You know, when I did this I just did it for fun. Something to do, something therapeutic.â''<ref name="videogum" />
==Music videos== Gormley's debut music video is for the song "Beginnings", which includes still images of scenery in his native Pensacola. The music video features an appearance by model Ashton Shane, who is also a [[VJ (media personality)|VJ]] for ''The Uncharted Zone''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.valdostadailytimes.com/elizabethbutler/local_story_336232459.html|title=Ashton Shane: Former Nashville resident on primetime TV show|last=Butler|first=Elizabeth|date=December 2, 2007|publisher=''[[The Valdosta Daily Times]]''|accessdate=2010-01-27}}</ref> ''[[Woot]]'' found the song "thought-provoking" and noted the profound insights offered by the lyrics.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.woot.com/Blog/ViewEntry.aspx?Id=7185|title=http://www.woot.com/Blog/ViewEntry.aspx?Id=7185|title=Once Upon A Gormley|last=Toon|first=Jason|date=January 22, 2009|publisher=''[[Woot]]''|accessdate=2010-02-10}}</ref> Gormley considers the song his personal favorite.<ref name="videogum" />
The "Little Wings" music video includes footage of [[Gull|seagulls]] in flight, as Gormley sings in front of ocean scenes. Gormley and his music video for "Little Wings" were featured on the website of Colorado-based newspaper ''[[Westword]]'', who remarked "there's something strangely appealing about Gormley...I have to say that this song is actually pretty great".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.westword.com/backbeat/2009/10/freaky_friday_little_wings_-_m.php|title=Freaky Friday: "Little Wings" - Mark Gormley|last=Casciato|first=Cory|date=October 16, 2009|publisher=''[[Westword]]''|accessdate=2010-01-08}}</ref> ''[[Stereogum|Videogum]]'' listed the "Little Wings" music video as one of the best [[viral videos]] of 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://videogum.com/archives/viral_video/the_best_viral_videos_of_2009_105741.html|title=The Best Viral Videos of 2009: A Retrospective|date=December 15, 2009|publisher=''[[Stereogum|Videogum]]''|accessdate=2010-01-13}}</ref>
"Gray Days" is one of Gormley's darkest songs, that ''[[LimeLife]]'' referred to as a "moving, Zeppelinesque tribute".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.limelife.com/channel-music/486.html|title=Mark Gormley is a Genius|date=January 14, 2009|publisher=''[[LimeLife]]''|accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref>
The music video for "Stars" shows Gormley performing the song while backed by footage of the night sky and the beaches of [[Perdido Key, Florida]].
[[Image:Without You.jpg|thumb|left|Mark Gormley in the music video for the song "Without You"]]
Gormley's breakthrough music video is for "Without You", released in 2008.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.urlesque.com/2010/01/20/mark-gormley-new-video/|title=Mark Gormley's New Video - A Legend Returns|last=Zweigart|first=Will|date=January 20, 2010|publisher=''Urlesque''|accessdate=2010-01-28}}</ref> "Without You" is a love song about heartbreak and loneliness<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.totallycrap.com/magazine/mark_gormley_needs_you/|title=Mark Gormley Needs You|publisher=''TC Magazine''|accessdate=2010-01-14}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nme.com/awards/video/id/87nkJquHnAU|title=Without You - Mark Gormley Video|publisher=''[[NME]]''|accessdate=2010-01-15}}</ref> that music website ''The Daily Swarm'' described as a "soft metal masterpiece".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thedailyswarm.com/swarm/mark-gormley-music-video-star/|title=Mark Gormley, Music Video Star...|last=Roberts|first=Todd|date=January 13, 2009|publisher=''The Daily Swarm''|accessdate=2010-01-07}}</ref> Alternative culture magazine ''Coilhouse'' called the track "an honest, well-crafted song" and noted Gormley's "soulful voice".<ref name="Coilhouse" /> ''[[Pensacola News Journal]]'' described the music video as "a frenetic mix of Gormley, scenic backdrops and a lovely young lady".<ref name="PNJ" /> Media journal ''[[BuzzFeed]]'' considered "Without You" to be a contender for 'Video of the Year'<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buzzfeed.com/percivalbright/music-video-of-the-year-3vd|title=Music Video of the Year|last=Bright|first=Percy|publisher=''[[BuzzFeed]]''|accessdate=2010-01-13}}</ref> and listed it among the 'Most Memorable Amateur Music Videos of the 2000s'.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.buzzfeed.com/awesomer/most-memorable-amateur-music-videos-of-the-2000s|title=Most Memorable Amateur Music Videos of the 2000s|last=Ringerud|first=Tanner|publisher=''[[BuzzFeed]]''|accessdate=2011-01-26}}</ref> On January 14, 2009, "Without You" was named a viral video by music magazine ''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]'' and ''[[Comedy Central]]''.<ref name="Blender" /><ref>{{cite web|url=http://ccinsider.comedycentral.com/2009/01/14/mark-gormley-parlays-one-intense-song-into-viral-video-god-dom/|title=Mark Gormley Parlays One Intense Song into Viral Video God-dom |last=March|first=Eric|date=January 14, 2009|publisher=''[[Comedy Central]]''|accessdate=2010-01-15}}</ref> On January 16, 2009, "Without You" was the daily featured music video on the website ''[[IAC (company)|Today's BIG Thing]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.todaysbigthing.com/music/2009/01/16|title=Mark Gormley's "Without You"|date=January 16, 2009|publisher=''[[IAC (company)|Today's BIG Thing]]''|accessdate=2011-01-25}}</ref> The music video achieved cult status through word-of-mouth and blog posts.<ref name="PNJ" /> When asked about the success of "Without You", Phil Thomas Katt stated: ''âIt spread like wildfire. I started hearing from folks all over the country. Mark never cared about being a celebrity, but the interest was there.â''<ref name="PNJ" /> In January 2011, "Without You" was featured on [[truTV]]'s ''[[The Smoking Gun Presents: World's Dumbest...|The Smoking Gun Presents: World's Dumbest]]'' ''Performers #6''.<ref name="truTV">{{cite web|url=http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6zJ_YZg2hJ8|title=World's Dumbest Performers 6 #17|date=January 20, 2011|publisher=''[[truTV]]''|accessdate=2011-01-21}}</ref> Commentators on the music video included actor [[Daniel Baldwin]], comedian [[Loni Love]], and writers [[Billy Kimball]] and Michael Loftus.<ref name="truTV" /> Loni Love criticized Gormley's choice of clothing, whereas Michael Loftus commented "you don't expect him to have a golden throat like that".<ref name="truTV" />
Gormley's missed opportunites and sudden fame were parodied in the music video for "The Cries in Our Eyes". During the course of the video, Gormley is depicted performing in front of famous [[landmarks]] from around the world and being photographed by [[paparazzi]].<ref name="videogum2" /> According to Missouri newsweekly ''[[Riverfront Times]]'', the music video created "the Mark Gormley tour that could have been".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://blogs.riverfronttimes.com/atoz/2009/03/st_louis_cheesy_music_video_mark_gormley_cries_in_our_eyes_arch.php|title=St. Louis Achieves Cheesy Music Video Fame!|last=Levitt|first=Aimee|date=March 3, 2009|publisher=''[[Riverfront Times]]''|accessdate=2010-01-07}}</ref>
The music video for "Sing Me Your Song" largely takes place on the [[Moon]] and in space.<ref name="Metro 2" /> The video capitalised on Gormley's success by featuring [[product placement]] for the [[Cheetos]] snack food.<ref name="Metro 2" /><ref name="Video Static">{{cite web|url=http://www.videostatic.com/vs/2010/01/diversion-mark-gormley-sing-me-your-song.html|title=DIVERSION: Mark Gormley "Sing Me Your Song"|last=Gottlieb|first=Steven|date=January 8, 2010|publisher=''Video Static''|accessdate=2010-01-08}}</ref> Music website ''Video Static'' described the song as "haunting" and praised the music videos use of product placement.<ref name="Video Static" /> Gormley opted to receive no money from the product placement deal, giving all revenue to ''The Uncharted Zone'' to help them during the difficult economy.
Gormley's music video for the song "All We Need" was released on June 27, 2010. It marks the final music video from his debut album. Gormley plans to write and record new songs in the future.<ref name="G4TV" /> A Mark Gormley DVD is also in production. ==Recordings== {{Infobox album | <!-- See Wikipedia:WikiProject_Albums --> Name = Mark Gormley | Type = studio | Artist = Mark Gormley | Cover = MarkGormleycover.jpg | Released = 2009 | Recorded = | Genre = [[Rock music|Rock]], [[acoustic music|acoustic rock]], [[folk rock]] | Length = 39:47 | Label = UZ Media | Producer = |}} Mark Gormley's self-titled debut album of original recordings has been released via ''The Uncharted Zone''.
===Track listing=== # "Beginnings" - 4:40 # "Little Wings" - 3:54 # "All We Need" - 7:48 # "Gray Days" - 5:01 # "Sing Me Your Song" - 5:58 # "Stars" - 4:36 # "The Cries in Our Eyes" - 3:58 # "Without You - 3:52 All tracks written and performed by Mark Gormley<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.theunchartedzone.com/MarkGormleyCD.htm|title=A Music CD From Gulf Coast Singer/Songwriter Mark Gormley|publisher=''The Uncharted Zone''|accessdate=2010-06-23}}</ref>
